p: It is widely accepted that the experience of pain should be considered through an interdisciplinary approach. Support programs, and in particular those including the Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), appear to be effective in increasing knowledge about primary dysmenorrhea and reconstructing dysfunctional cognition with more rational ones, as well as increasing self-regulation skills. These interventions result in a better understanding of the meaning of pain, decrease of symptoms, and reduction of analgesic use. 70, 71 Well-designed studies are needed for a deeper understanding of the relationship between common mental health conditions and primary dysmenorrhea that will ensure a better clinical approach.
